Description: THE SIHEK (GUAM KINGFISHER, TODIRAMPHUS CINNAMOMINUS) IS ENDEMIC TO GUAM BUT BECAME EXTINCT IN THEWILD BY 1988 DUE TO PREDATION BY INVASIVE BROWN TREESNAKES (BOIGA IRREGULARIS  WILES ET AL. 2003). TWENTYNINEOF THE LAST WILD SIHEK WERE RESCUED TO CAPTIVITY TO START A CONSERVATION BREEDING PROGRAM, SAVING THESPECIES FROM EXTINCTION. HOWEVER, THE CAPTIVE POPULATION CURRENTLY CONSISTS OF ONLY 137 INDIVIDUALS(INCLUDING 49 FEMALES) AND IS PREDICTED TO DECLINE TO EXTINCTION UNDER CURRENT MANAGEMENT (JOHNSON ET AL.2015  TRASK ET AL. 2021). TO EXPAND THE CURRENT POPULATION AND PREVENT COMPLETE EXTINCTION OF THE SPECIES,THE SIHEK RECOVERY TEAM  COMPRISED OF CONSERVATION TRANSLOCATION EXPERTS FROM THE ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETYOF LONDON (ZSL), UNIVERSITY OF BERN, IUCN, GUAM DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE DIVISION OF AQUATIC  WILDLIFE RESOURCES (DAWR), GUAM KINGFISHER SPECIES SURVIVAL PLAN, AND PACIFIC ISLANDS FISH   WILDLIFEOFFICEHAS IDENTIFIED PALMYRA ATOLL AS A SUITABLE FIRST RELEASE SITE FOR SIHEK OUTSIDE THEIR HISTORICAL RANGE.RELEASES ARE SET TO BEGIN IN MID-2023 AND WILL MARK THE SPECIES FIRST RETURN TO THE WILD IN OVER 30 YEARS.THE SIHEK TEAM RECOGNIZES THAT THIS STRATEGY, WHILE POTENTIALLY BENEFICIAL, INVOLVES RISK TO SIHEK THEMSELVESAND TO THE RECIPIENT ECOSYSTEM.IN THIS PROJECT, THE RECOVERY TEAM SEEKS TO FILL SOME KEY GAPS, SPECIFICALLY TO (I) REFINE CURRENT KNOWLEDGE(PRIORS) FOR THIS HIGHLY UNCERTAIN SYSTEM, (II) FORMALIZE ALTERNATIVE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS, (III) SET STATEDEPENDENTRESPONSES (INCLUDING TRIGGERS POINTS AND POSSIBLE EXIT STRATEGIES) BASED ON POTENTIAL OUTCOMES,AND (IV) SET UP A PROTOCOL TO UPDATE MODELS ACCURATELY AND PROMPTLY AS MONITORING DATA ARE COLLECTED. OURPROPOSAL AIMS TO FILL THESE GAPS BY RECRUITING A POSTDOCTORAL RESEARCH ASSOCIATE (PDRA) TO OVERSEE ADAPTIVEMANAGEMENT OF THE PALMYRA ATOLL SIHEK PROGRAM.THE PDRA WILL FOCUS ON THREE UNCERTAIN, AND HENCE RISKY, ASPECTS OF THIS ASSISTED COLONIZATION. FIRST, THEYWILL ANALYZE QUANTITATIVELY THE EXPECTED DYNAMICS OF SIHEK DEMOGRAPHY, INCLUDING SUSTAINABLE HARVESTINGFROM THE CAPTIVE POPULATION AND MAXIMIZING ESTABLISHMENT SUCCESS ON PALMYRA ATOLL. THIS WILL INVOLVEUPDATING AN INTEGRATED POPULATION MODEL LINKING BOTH THE CAPTIVE AND WILD POPULATIONS. SECOND, THEY WILLSUPERVISE A DETAILED ASSESSMENT OF DISEASE RISKS, INCLUDING DEVISING METHODS TO MITIGATE RISKS TO SIHEK ANDTHE RECIPIENT ECOSYSTEM. THIS WILL INCLUDE ANALYSIS OF HEALTH SCREENING DATA FROM SIHEK IN A PRE-RELEASEQUARANTINE FACILITY, RELEASED SIHEK ON PALMYRA, AND OTHER SPECIES AT THE RELEASE SITE. THIRD, THEY WILL DEVELOPA BROAD ASSESSMENT OF ECOSYSTEM IMPACTS, WITH A FOCUS ON MEASURING AND MITIGATING THE PREDATION IMPACTSOF SIHEK ON THE RECIPIENT ECOSYSTEM, IN CLOSE COLLABORATION WITH PARTNERS.OUR AIM IS TO INCREASE THE LIKELIHOOD OF SUCCESSFUL ESTABLISHMENT OF THE PALMYRA SIHEK POPULATION ANDMINIMIZE THE RISK TO THE RECIPIENT ECOSYSTEM FROM DOING SO. ASSISTED COLONIZATION IS INHERENTLY RISKY YET ITIS INCREASINGLY BEING CALLED UPON FOR SPECIES RECOVERY. OUR PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A BLUEPRINT THAT CAN BEAPPLIED TO OTHER ASSISTED COLONIZATIONS IN THE U.S. AND BEYOND.

THE WESTERN ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES (WAFWA)HAS MAINTAINED LONG STANDING, STATE-LEAD LANDSCAPE LEVEL CONSERVATION PRIORITIES THROUGH ITS INITIATIVES, COMMITTEES, AND ASSIGNED WORKING GROUPS. MUCH OF THIS WORK REQUIRES FREQUENT COMMUNICATIONS AND COORDINATION AMONG MEMBER STATES AND BETWEEN VARIOUS FEDERAL AGENCIES OF DOI AND USFWS AND NEARLY ALWAYS INCLUDES PARTICIPATION AMONG THE 5 REGIONAL FWS OFFICES AND AT TIMES NATIONAL FWS LEADERSHIP. GIVEN THE SUCCESS OF WAFWAS CURRENT EFFORTS AND A DESIRE FOR GREATER LANDSCAPE LEVEL COLLABORATION BETWEEN WAFWA STATES AND OUR FEDERAL PARTNERS, WAFWA AND THE FWS JOINTLY SEEK TO ENTER INTO AN AGREEMENT THAT WILL SUPPORT THESE SHARED GOALS WITHIN WAFWA AND ASSIST THE FWS IN THEIR EFFORTS TO CREATE AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF LANDSCAPE PRIORITIES AMONG ALL FOUR REGIONAL ASSOCIATIONS. CURRENT WAFWA PRIORITIES ARE MULTIJURISDICTIONAL AND VARY FROM BIOME SPECIFIC PRIORITIES, PRINCIPLES OF LANDSCAPE CONNECTIVITY, AND SPECIES SPECIFIC INVENTORY, ASSESSMENT, AND RECOVERY EFFORTS. EXAMPLES OF PRIORITIES AND APPLICABLE WAFWA COMMITTEES ANDWORKSHOPS INCLUDE: BIOME: SAGE BRUSH, GRASSLANDS, RIPARIAN CORRIDORS, WATER RESILIENCE. LANDSCAPE CONNECTIVITY:MIGRATION CORRIDORS, FISH PASSAGE, AND IMPROVED HABITAT PERMEABILITY. SPECIES PLANNING: MONARCHS, BLACK FOOTEDFERRETS, WESTERN TROUT, DESERT FISH, WILD SHEEP, SAGE GROUSE, MULE DEER, FOREST CARNIVORES, AND COMMITTEES:ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT, ANIMAL MOVEMENT AND MIGRATION, FISHERIES, NON-GAME, HABITAT, AND EXECUTIVE COMMITTEES WORKSHOPS: ESA, SAGE AND SHARP-TAILS, BLACK BEAR, MOUNTAIN LION, AND SWAP PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION. WAFWA RECOGNIZES THAT COORDINATED LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION IN THE REGION CONTINUES TO BE IMPERATIVE FOR MANY FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES THAT COMPLETE THEIR LIFE REQUIREMENTS IN ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS THAT CROSS POLITICAL BOUNDARIES. WORKING AT THE LANDSCAPE SCALES REQUIRES BROADER STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT, EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION, TRANSPARENCY AND ACCOUNTABILITY ACROSS MULTIPLE AGENCIES, LANDOWNERSHIPS, AND POTENTIALLY OPPOSING POLITICAL REALITIES. THE ASSIGNED WESTERN COORDINATOR AND ALL SUPPORTING ROLES WORK UNDER WAFWA LEADERSHIP AND WILL PROVIDE A CENTRAL POINT OF COMMUNICATION AS A LIAISON TO THE USFWS AND THE LARGER FISH AND WILDLIFE LANDSCAPE COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE, INCLUDING STATE, TRIBAL, FEDERAL, NON-GOVERNMENTAL, AND UNIVERSITY PARTNERS.

OVER THE COURSE OF THE VIRTUAL SUMMIT (2020) AND THE IN-PERSON SUMMIT (2022) OF THE CENTRAL GRASSLANDS ROADMAP (CGR), DIVERSE NEEDS WERE IDENTIFIED AND WORKGROUPS SUBSEQUENTLY FORMED. MANY OF THE 600  PARTICIPANTS DISCUSSED THE NEED TO INVEST IN THE SOCIAL   HUMAN ASPECTS OF GRASSLANDS, INCLUDING WORKING TO UNDERSTAND THE SOCIAL INEQUITIES, SOCIAL ISSUES AND HUMAN-DIMENSION FACETS THAT PUT GRASSLANDS AT RISK. NONETHELESS, A SOCIAL WORKING GROUP PER SE HAS NOT YET BEEN FORMED AND DEVELOPING THIS SPHERE OF ENGAGEMENT REQUIRES ATTENTION. THE INDIGENOUS KINSHIP CIRCLE (IKC) HAS INVESTED SIGNIFICANT TIME IN BUILDING A WORKING GROUP (CIRCLE) FOR BROAD INDIGENOUS ENGAGEMENT, INCLUDING A FOCUS ON SOCIAL EQUITY AND RESPECT OF DIVERSE WORLDVIEWS AND KNOWLEDGE SYSTEMS. THE COMMISSION FOR ENVIRONMENTAL COOPERATION (CEC) HAS INCLUDED A HUMAN DIMENSIONS PILLAR AS ONE OF THREE PRINCIPLE PROJECT AREAS FOR THEIR GRASSLANDS INITIATIVE. PARTICIPATION BY IKC MEMBERS IN THESE ACTIVITIES HAS DEMONSTRATED A CLEAR NEED FOR BRIDGING SOCIAL SCIENCE INVESTIGATION IN REGARDS TO GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT (VARIOUSLY DEFINED), WITH BROAD ENGAGEMENT AND SOCIAL EQUITY RESEARCH ACROSS THE BIOME AND HER PEOPLES. SUPPORT FROM THE USFWS WILL HELP ADVANCE AND BETTER INTEGRATE SOCIAL AND CULTURAL NEEDS FOR THE GRASSLAND BIOME OVER THE NEXT 2.5 YEARS.

THE FOLLOWING SCOPE OF WORK WILL BE OVERSEEN BY THE ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES (AFWA) DIRECTOR OF CONSERVATION INITIATIVES AND CARRIED OUT BY ONE PART-TIME CONTRACTOR. THEY WILL PROVIDE SCIENCE SUPPORT AND SERVICE AND BE THE POINT OF CONTACT ON FISH   WILDLIFE HEALTH AND ONE HEALTH FOR STATE AND TERRITORIAL FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES (STATES), PROVINCES, US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS), OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES, AND NONGOVERNMENTAL CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS BY 1) SERVING AS CONVEYORS FOR THE STATES, FWS, AND OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES TO INFORM, DISCUSS, AND DEVELOP ACTIONS ON PRIORITY FISH AND WILDLIFE HEALTH AND ONE HEALTH WORK  2) LEADING AND FACILITATING COMMUNICATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE HEALTH AND ONE HEALTH BETWEEN THE STATES, THE FWS, OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES, NGOS  3) PROVIDING STAFFING TO KEY PARTNERSHIPS, COMMITTEES, AND WORK GROUPS TO ADVANCE COLLABORATION ON FISH AND WILDLIFE HEALTH AND ONE HEALTH  4) CONDUCTING PROJECT WORK THAT LEADS TO IMPROVEMENTS IN AND USE OF SCIENCE, TOOLS, AND POLICIES THAT AFFECT FISH AND WILDLIFE HEALTH.

THE WESTERN ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES (WAFWA) AND THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (HEREAFTER SERVICE) SEEK TO ESTABLISH A REGIONAL WILDLIFE HEALTH COORDINATION EFFORT TO FACILITATE THE PRIORITIZATION AND ASSESSMENT OF WESTERN WILDLIFE HEALTH NEEDS AND PROVIDE NATIONAL COORDINATION BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE OTHER 3 REGIONAL ASSOCIATIONS. THIS EFFORT WILL BE ADMINISTERED SOLELY THROUGH WAFWA S EXECUTIVE OFFICE UNDER THE TERMS OF THIS AGREEMENT WHICH ESTABLISHES A LEAD REGIONAL WILDLIFE HEALTH COORDINATOR POSITION, SELECTED BY AND OPERATING IN SERVICE TO WAFWA MEMBERS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PARTNERSHIP IS TO HELP ADDRESS THE INCREASING THREAT OF WILDLIFE-RELATED EMERGING DISEASES AFFECTING THE HEALTH OF OUR VALUED WILDLIFE RESOURCES. SUCH THREATS DEMONSTRATE THE CRITICAL NEED FOR THE CREATION OF REGIONAL WILDLIFE HEALTH COORDINATION WITHIN EACH OF THE REGIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE  ASSOCIATIONS (I.E., NEAFWA, SEAFWA, MAFWA AND WAFWA). THE COORDINATOR POSITION WILL SERVE WAFWA AND WORK WITH AFWAS FISH AND WILDLIFE HEALTH COORDINATOR AND WAFWA COMMITTEES AND WORK GROUPS (SUCH AS WAFWAS WILDLIFE HEALTH COMMITTEE WHC) AS ASSIGNED BY LEADERSHIP TO BRING WILDLIFE AGENCIES TO READINESS AND VOLUNTARILY COORDINATE THEIR EFFORTS REGIONALLY. THE ASSIGNED REGIONAL COORDINATOR AND ALL SUPPORTING ROLES WORK UNDER WAFWA LEADERSHIP AND WILL PROVIDE A CENTRAL POINT OF COMMUNICATION AS A LIAISON TO THE FISH AND WILDLIFE HEALTH COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE, INCLUDING STATE, TRIBAL, FEDERAL, NON-GOVERNMENTAL, AND UNIVERSITY PARTNERS.

EXCELLENCE AND SUPPORT PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OF WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS AND MANAGERS. ALSO HELPING THE AGENCY RECRUIT FROM BOTH THE PROFESSIONAL AND COLLEGIATE RANKS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES: TWS AND FWS WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY TO ENSURE THAT THE OVERALL OBJECTIVES AND PERFORMANCE GOALS OUTLINED IN THIS PROPOSAL ARE ACHIEVED. THAT INCLUDES REGULAR MONITORING, ASSESSMENT, AND, WHERE APPROPRIATE, ADJUSTMENTS TO ACTIVITIES TO SUPPORT OR ENHANCE PERFORMANCE OUTCOMES. THROUGHOUT THE COURSE OF THIS AGREEMENT, TWS AND FWS MAY SWAP, CUSTOMIZE OR EMPHASIZE SPECIFIC. ELEMENTS OUTLINED BELOW IN RESPONSE TO THE DYNAMIC NEEDS AND OR OPPORTUNITIES PRESENTED THROUGH THIS. STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP. CORE PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL CENTER AROUND: PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT COLLABORATION AND TALENT RECRUITMENT ( 10,000)TWS WILL LEVERAGE ITS COMMUNICATIONS NETWORK AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES TO ASSIST. FWS IN KEEPING ITS STAFF WELL-INFORMED AND TRAINED, WHILE ALSO HELPING THE AGENCY RECRUIT THE BEST. AND THE BRIGHTEST FROM BOTH THE PROFESSIONAL AND COLLEGIATE RANKS. SUPPORTING THE PARTICIPATION OF NATIVE AMERICAN COLLEGE STUDENTS IN TWS ANNUAL CONFERENCE ( 40,000)TWS IS COMMITTED TO IDENTIFYING AND IMPLEMENTING SUSTAINABLE SOLUTIONS TO ADDRESSING BARRIERS. THAT HAVE LED TO A LACK OF DIVERSITY WITHIN THE WILDLIFE PROFESSION. A MORE DIVERSE PROFESSIONAL COMMUNITY IMPROVES APPROACHES TO WILDLIFE SCIENCE AND MANAGEMENT NEEDED TO ADDRESS THE COMPLEXITY OF CONSERVATION CHALLENGES FACED TODAY. THROUGH THE CONTINUED SUPPORT OF PARTNERS LIKE FWS, TWS HAS BEEN ABLE TO EFFECTIVELY FACILITATE AND PROMOTE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT. OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH PROGRAMS LIKE THE NATIVE STUDENT PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT (NSPD) PROGRAM, WHICH JUST COMPLETED ITS 15TH YEAR.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A COLLABORATIVE MODEL FOR THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO MEANINGFULLY ENGAGE WITH TRIBAL COMMUNITIES AND DEVELOP LONG-TERM PARTNERSHIPS IN SUPPORT OF SHARED PRIORITY RESOURCES. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL HELP THE SERVICE INCLUDE INDIGENOUS TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE (ITEK) INTO CONSERVATION STRATEGIES TO SUPPORT RIVERCANE RESTORATION ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST. RIVERCANE IS A NATIVE BAMBOO, UPON WHICH MANY AT-RISK AND THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES DEPEND (ESPECIALLY BIRDS). BEYOND ITS VAST ECOLOGICAL VALUE, IT IS ALSO AN IMPORTANT CULTURAL RESOURCE TO ALMOST EVERY TRIBAL COMMUNITY IN THE SOUTHEAST. THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND UPON EXISTING EFFORTS TO INCLUDE RIVERCANE AS A CULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCE INDICATOR WITHIN THE SOUTHEAST CONSERVATION BLUEPRINT AND TEST CONCEPTUAL MODELS DEVELOPED DURING THE 2021 RIVERCANE RESTORATION ALLIANCE WORKSHOP.

DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS TO ACCELERATE RESPONSIBLE DEVELOPMENT OF RENEWABLE ENERGY IN THE SOUTHEASTERN USA: GOLDEN EAGLES AND WIND ENERGY WE PROPOSE TO USE EXISTING AND NEW TELEMETRY DATA TO IDENTIFY DISTRIBUTION AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF GOLDEN EAGLES IN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES, THEN DELIVER DECISION-SUPPORT TOOLS TO HELP ACCELERATE RESPONSIBLE DEVELOPMENT OF RENEWABLE ENERGY IN THE REGION. INTERACTIONS BETWEEN GOLDEN EAGLES AND WIND TURBINES SLOW RESPONSIBLE DEVELOPMENT OF WIND ENERGY THROUGHOUT THE USA. POPULATIONS OF GOLDEN EAGLES IN EASTERN NORTH AMERICA ARE SMALL, POORLY KNOWN, AND A HIGH CONSERVATION PRIORITY. FURTHERMORE, ALTHOUGH THE SOUTHEASTERN USA CURRENTLY DOES NOT SUPPORT SUBSTANTIAL WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT, RAPID GROWTH IS EXPECTED IN THE NEAR FUTURE. MUCH OF THIS PLANNED GROWTH IS IN AREAS WHERE GOLDEN EAGLES ARE THOUGHT TO OCCUR. AS SUCH, THERE IS AN IMPORTANT PRIORITY FOR DEVELOPMENT OF DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS THAT CAN GUIDE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS TO REDUCE THE THREAT OF INTERACTIONS BETWEEN GOLDEN EAGLES AND WIND TURBINES THROUGHOUT THIS REGION. THIS PROJECT WILL RELY ON ANALYSIS OF TWO TYPES OF DATA. OUR TEAM HAS DEPLOYED GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM TRACKING (TELEMETRY) DEVICES ON MORE THAN 120 GOLDEN EAGLES AND DEPLOYED MORE THAN 250 CAMERA TRAPS THROUGHOUT EASTERN NORTH AMERICA. WE WILL USE BOTH THESE DATA TO IDENTIFY GEOGRAPHIC AREAS WITH KNOWN GOLDEN EAGLES BUT FOR WHICH WE HAVE NO GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM TELEMETRY DATA. WE WILL TARGET THOSE AREAS FOR TRAPPING, AIMING TO DEPLOY TRANSMITTERS ON AN ADDITIONAL 5-10 BIRDS IN THOSE AREAS. TO MAP GOLDEN EAGLES EMPIRICAL DISTRIBUTION, WE WILL USE A SUITE OF DATA SOURCES, INCLUDING TELEMETRY, EBIRD, CAMERA TRAP, AND OTHER OBSERVATION DATA. WE WILL THEN CREATE MODELS OF RELATIVE ABUNDANCE THAT INTEGRATE GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM TELEMETRY DATA AND COUNTS OF EAGLES FROM CAMERA TRAPS. TO IDENTIFY REGION-SPECIFIC FLIGHT ALTITUDES, WE WILL USE ALTITUDE DATA OBTAINED FROM THE TELEMETRY DATA TO MODEL VARIATION IN FLIGHT ALTITUDE AS A RESPONSE TO REGION, WEATHER, TOPOGRAPHY, AND LAND COVER. WE WILL THEN IDENTIFY AREAS WHERE FLIGHT ALTITUDES OF EAGLES ARE EXPECTED TO INTERSECT WITH BLADES OF CURRENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS OF WIND TURBINES (ABOUT 50-250 METERS ABOVE SURFACE).THREE KEY PRODUCTS OF THIS WORK WILL BE MAPS OF (1) DISTRIBUTION  (2) RELATIVE ABUNDANCE  AND (3) REGION-SPECIFIC FLIGHT ALTITUDES OF GOLDEN EAGLES IN THE SOUTHEASTERN U.S. WE WILL PROVIDE ELECTRONIC FILES OF THESE MAPS DIRECTLY TO THE U.S. FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE AND MAKE THEM AVAILABLE TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC ON OUR WEBSITE. WE WILL ALSO INCORPORATE THEM INTO SCIENTIFIC ARTICLES STEMMING FROM THIS WORK AND THAT WE WILL PUBLISH IN PEER-REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS. FINALLY, WE ALSO ANTICIPATE PRESENTING THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK TO U.S. FISH   WILDLIFE AND REGIONAL BIOLOGISTS WITH ONE OR MORE WEB-BASED PRESENTATIONS.THIS WORK WILL (A) IDENTIFY STEPS TO ACCELERATE RESPONSIBLE DEVELOPMENT OF RENEWABLE ENERGY (A DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR PRIORITY), (B) PROVIDE HIGH QUALITY SCIENCE AND DECISION SUPPORT FOR PROGRAMS AND PARTNERS BY PROVIDING PEER-REVIEWED SCIENCE (A SCIENCE APPLICATIONS AND MIGRATORY BIRD PROGRAMS PRIORITY), AND (C) PROVIDE DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS AND FILL KNOWLEDGE GAPS RELATED TO SUSTAINABILITY OF BIRDS (BOTH SOUTHEAST REGIONAL U.S. FISH   WILDLIFE PRIORITIES).

AN INTERNSHIP PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES REAL-WORLD EXPERIENCE IN FIELD RESEARCH AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT, AND DEVELOPS PROFESSIONAL AND LEADERSHIP SKILLS. AFTER COMPLETING OUR PROGRAM, UNDERGRADUATES WILL BE MORE AWARE OF, AND BETTER PREPARED FOR, CONSERVATION CAREER OPPORTUNITIES AND POST-GRADUATE INTERNSHIP PROGRAMS SUCH AS THE USFWSS PATHWAYS AND DIRECTORATE FELLOWS PROGRAMS.

UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION (NFWF) AND U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE (FWS) WILL MANAGE THE DELAWARE WATERSHED CONSERVATION FUND. AUTHORIZED BY THE NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION ESTABLISHMENT ACT, 16 U.S.C. 3701 OF 1984, NFWF WILL ASSIST FWS BY DEVELOPING A COMPETITIVE GRANT PROGRAM WITH THE GOAL OF IMPROVING RESTORATION AND PROTECTION OF THE RESOURCES IN THE DELAWARE RIVER WATERSHED BY ENHANCING EFFORTS TO COORDINATE THE MANY PARTNERS. NFWF HAS A LONGSTANDING COMMITMENT TO WATERSHED RESTORATION AND STEWARDSHIP, FOCUSED ON DEMONSTRABLE IMPROVEMENTS FOR NATURAL RESOURCES AND SOCIAL VALUES, INCLUDING NATIVE BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF KEY INDICATOR SPECIES. NFWF HAS A TRACK RECORD OF ENGAGEMENT WITH COMMUNITY LEADERS AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND HAS PREVIOUSLY ASSISTED FWS USING THIS PROVEN GRANT PROGRAM MODEL. THE DELAWARE WATERSHED CONSERVATION FUND (DWCF) WILL MAXIMIZE CONSERVATION, BOLSTER THE ECONOMY, FURTHER PROTECT COMMUNITIES, IMPROVE HUMAN HEALTH, PROVIDE GREATER OUTDOOR RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES, AND HELP BUILD A MORE ADAPTABLE WATERSHED FOR ALL CITIZENS TO ENJOY TODAY AND INTO THE FUTURE.

UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION (NFWF) AND U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE (FWS) WILL MANAGE THE CHESAPEAKE WATERSHED INVESTMENTS FOR LANDSCAPE DEFENSE (WILD) PROGRAM. AUTHORIZED BY THE NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION ESTABLISHMENT ACT, 16 U.S.C. 3701 OF 1984, NFWF WILL ASSIST FWS BY IMPLEMENTING YEAR TWO OF A COMPETITIVE GRANT PROGRAM WITH THE GOAL OF CONSERVING, STEWARDING, AND ENHANCING FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITATS AND RELATED CONSERVATION VALUES IN THE CHESAPEAKE BAY, BUILDING CAPACITY OF REGIONAL PARTNERS TO ADDRESS SHARED RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION PRIORITIES, AND ENHANCING COORDINATION AMONG FEDERAL, STATE, LOCAL, AND REGIONAL ENTITIES WORKING TOWARD SHARED GOALS FOR SUSTAINING NATURAL RESOURCES AND HUMAN COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE WATERSHED.

THE NORTH AMERICAN SAGEBRUSH STEPPE HAS BEEN CONVERTED AND ALTERED EXTENSIVELY, WITH CONCOMITANT DECLINES IN SAGEBRUSH-ASSOCIATED WILDLIFE. THE RECENT SAGEBRUSH CONSERVATION DESIGN (SCD) EFFORTS PROVIDE VALUABLE, BROAD-SCALE INFERENCE ABOUT CORE SAGEBRUSH AREAS (CSAS)AND GROWTH OPPORTUNITY AREAS (GOAS. A KEY NEXT STEP IS TO CLARIFY THE FINER-SCALE, WITHIN-LANDSCAPE HABITAT ELEMENTS THAT ARE CRITICAL TO SUPPORT DECLINING SAGEBRUSH SPECIES. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO QUANTIFY THE SAGEBRUSH ATTRIBUTES OF AREAS WITHIN LANDSCAPES THAT ARE CONSISTENTLY UTILIZED BY THE THREE SAGEBRUSH-OBLIGATE SONGBIRDS (BREWER S SPARROW, SAGEBRUSH SPARROW, SAGE THRASHER)FOR NESTING, AND THAT TEND TO RESULT IN HIGHER NEST SURVIVAL. THE PROJECT LEVERAGES AN EXISTING AND SPATIALLY-EXPLICIT DATASET OF THOUSANDS OF NESTS AND ACCOMPANYING HABITAT DATA FROM THREE UNIQUE STUDY AREAS IN WYOMING AND MONTANA SPANNING FOUR TO 12 YEARS. THE IDENTIFICATION OF FINER- RESOLUTION SPECIES-HABITAT RELATIONSHIPS AS RELATED TO COARSER-SCALE SCD TEMPORAL TRENDS WILL PROVIDE PRACTITIONERS WITH NOVEL INFORMATION TO GUIDE SAGEBRUSH CONSERVATION IMPLEMENTATION ACTIONS.
THIS STUDY AIMS TO LINK THE ECOLOGY OF THE FERRUGINOUS HAWK WITH ITS ENVIRONMENT ACROSS THE SPECIES RANGE, TO BETTER INFORM MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION.

MASS AUDUBONS COASTAL WATERBIRD PROGRAM WILL CONDUCT PROTECTIVE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR PIPING PLOVER, LEAST TERN, RED KNOT AND MIGRATORY SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION NEEDS AND MEASURES AT THE HANSCOM AIR FORCE BASE, FOURTH CLIFF RECREATION AREA IN SCITUATE, MASSACHUSETTS. THE WORK WILL INCLUDE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH OPPORTUNITIES TO MAINTAIN COMMUNITY SUPPORT FOR CONSERVING SHOREBIRDS AND INFORMING VISITORS TO FOURTH CLIFF ABOUT SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION AND RE-ESTABLISH BLUE MUSSELS ON THE TIDAL FLATS NEAR IN PARTNERSHIP WITH NORTH AND SOUTH RIVER WATERSHED ALLIANCE FOR MIGRATORY BIRD NOURISHMENT.SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL COMPLETE THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES IN 2023: 1. MEET THE GUIDELINES FOR ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION ON RECREATIONAL BEACHES  2. DOCUMENT PREDATOR ACTIVITY AND VANDALISM FOR POTENTIAL CONTROL MEASURES  3. ENGAGE AND EDUCATE VISITORS TO FOURTH CLIFF IN ORDER TO REDUCE THE LIKELIHOOD OF DISTURBANCE TO NESTING PIPING PLOVERS AND LEAST TERNS  4. DOCUMENT MIGRATORY SHOREBIRD USE OF THE SITE TO ASSESS OPPORTUNITIES FOR HABITAT IMPROVEMENT  AND 5. RESTORE BLUE MUSSEL BEDS AS A FORAGING RESOURCE FOR PROTECTED MIGRATORY SHOREBIRD SPECIES SUCH AS THE RUFA RED KNOT.

ACE WILL PROVIDE THE SERVICE WITH ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT FOR THE SCIENCE IN THE SERVICE FELLOWSHIP.  ACE WILL PROVIDE A PROGRAM STRUCTURE THAT ALLOWS FOR FWS STAFF TO OBTAIN ADDITIONAL PROJECT FOCUSED SUPPORT TO ACHIEVE ITS MISSION OF CONSERVING, PROTECTING, AND ENHANCING FISH, WILDLIFE, PLANTS, AND THEIR HABITATS FOR THE CONTINUING BENEFIT OF THE AMERICAN PEOPLE.ACE WILL RECRUIT AND FIELD UP TO SIX DIVERSE FELLOWS TO SERVE WITH THE FWS SCIENCE IN THE SERVICE FELLOWSHIP ACROSS REGION 8. ACE WILL PROVIDE SIX YOUNG ADULTS WITH HANDS-ON CONSERVATION AND CAREER DEVELOPMENT TRAINING THAT SUPPORTS DIVERSITY AND INCLUSION IN THE CONSERVATION WORKFORCE. SPECIFIC PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL BE DETERMINED BY THE NEEDS OF EACH SERVICE LOCATION BY FWS STAFF.

NORTH AMERICAN SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS ARE A REGIONAL PRIORITY OF THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS) AND OTHER DOI AGENCIES, SUCH AS THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM). TO EFFECTIVELY IMPLEMENT STRATEGIC HABITAT CONSERVATION (SHC), THE FWS SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM TEAM (SET) AND OTHERS WORKING IN SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS NEED TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE THREAT CLIMATE CHANGE POSES TO SHORT AND LONG-TERM RESILIENCE AND SUSTAINABILITY OF SAGEBRUSH BIOTIC COMMUNITIES AND ECOSYSTEM GOODS AND SERVICES THOSE COMMUNITIES PROVIDE. WE PROPOSE TO DELIVER TARGETED TRAINING TO ENHANCE LAND-MANAGERS ABILITIES TO ADDRESS SAGEBRUSH TREATS (E.G., LAND CONVERSATION, HABITAT FRAGMENTATION) IN THE CONTEXT OF CLIMATE CHANGE. WITHOUT THIS KNOWLEDGE, SAGEBRUSH BIOLOGISTS AND RESOURCE MANAGERS ARE UNABLE TO FULLY INTEGRATE CLIMATE IMPACTS AND ADAPTATION INTO SAGEBRUSH SHC. IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL DEVELOP A TRAINING SERIES MODELED AFTER THE SUCCESSFUL CLIMATE ADAPTATION FOR GRASSLANDS MANAGEMENT WORKSHOP AND INCLUDE A SERIES OF LIVE AND PRE-RECORDED CLIMATE SCIENCE WEBINARS LEADING UP TO A TWO-DAY CLIMATE ADAPTATION FOR SAGEBRUSH MANAGEMENT WORKSHOP IN 2024. AGENDA AND TOPICS WILL BE BASED IN PART ON IDENTIFIED GAPS EXPRESSED BY CURRENT SET MEMBERS IN THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITY TO MANAGE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS UNDER CHANGING CLIMATES AND WILL INCLUDE INVITED RESEARCHERS, WHO HAVE BEEN WORKING UNDER CASC GUIDANCE AS PRESENTERS.

THE INSTITUTE FOR CONSERVATION LEADERSHIP (ICL) IS UNIQUELY QUALIFIED TO RECEIVE THIS AWARD DUE TO THEIREXCEPTIONAL CAPABILITIES AND QUALIFICATIONS. THROUGH THEIR COLLABORATION WITH THE WILLIAM PENN FOUNDATION AND THEDELAWARE RIVER WATERSHED INITIATIVE, ICL WILL PROVIDE FACILITATION SERVICES AND LEADERSHIP COACHING TO THEDELAWARE RIVER WATERSHED CONSERVATION COLLABORATIVE. THEIR ORGANIZATIONAL EXPERTISE AND SKILLED FACILITATORS ANDCOACHES WILL ENSURE EFFICIENT COLLABORATION AMONG STAKEHOLDERS. ICL WILL EMPLOY TAILORED APPROACHES, INCLUDINGSHARED GOAL SETTING, STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT STRATEGIES, AND BREAKOUT SESSION FACILITATION AT THE 2023 DELAWARERIVER WATERSHED FORUM, TO SUPPORT THE COLLABORATIVE IN ACHIEVING THEIR OBJECTIVES EFFECTIVELY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS FOR THE ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES (AFWA) TO PARTNER WITH THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) TO PROVIDE SUPPORT AND COORDINATION ON ISSUES AND SUBJECTS WITHIN WILDLIFE CONSERVATION. THE SUBJECTS BEING FOCUSED ON WITHIN THE SCOPE OF WORK ARE FISH   WILDLIFE HEALTH, CLIMATE CHANGE, AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE CONSERVATION, INVASIVE SPECIES, LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION, BAT CONSERVATION, BIRD CONSERVATION AND INTERNATIONAL CONSERVATION. AFWA WILL SUPPORT AND COORDINATE THIS WORK ON THESE ISSUES BETWEEN STATES, FWS, OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES AND PRIVATE CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS. EACH INITIATIVE INVOLVES STAFFING AND LEADING COMMITTEES TO FORMULATE PLANS OF ACTIONS ON THESE ISSUES AS WELL AS PROJECT-BASED WORK OVER THE LIFE CYCLE OF THIS AWARD. AFWA WILL USE STAFF S TIME AS WELL AS INDEPENDENT CONTRACTORS TO PERFORM THE WORK DETAILED WITHIN THE SCOPE OF THIS AGREEMENT. PLEASE REFER TO THE SCOPE OF WORK FOR A MORE IN-DEPTH PLAN OF ACTION SURROUNDING THIS AGREEMENT.

THIS PROJECT WILL BE AN ACOUSTIC AND MIST-NET SURVEY OF JOINT BASE LANGLEY-EUSTIS, VIRGINIA FOR DETERMINING THE PRESENCE, SEASONAL ACTIVITY PATTERNS, AND DAY-ROOST USE OF THE ENDANGERED INDIANA BAT AND NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT AS WELL AS THE PROPOSED TRICOLOR BAT. WORK EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON THE BETHEL TRACT OF THE INSTALLATION. WORK WILL COMMENCE IN EARLY FALL OF 2023 AND PROCEED THROUGH SUMMER OF 2024. DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE OCCUPANCY HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS BY SPECIES BY SEASON, POTENTIAL DAY-ROOST SUITABILITY MODELING AND A BAT MANAGEMENT PLAN TO INFORM REGULATORY GUIDANCE AND INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANNING ON THE INSTALLATION. DATA FROM THIS STUDY WILL ALSO BE USED TO SUPPLEMENT LARGER REGION-WIDE EFFORTS BEING CONDUCTED BY THE VIRGINIA UNIT USEFUL TO U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, OTHER DOD INSTALLATIONS AND VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES.

THE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION INITIATIVE (WCI) WILL BETTER UNDERSTAND OCCURRENCE OF AT-RISK SPECIES ON PRIVATE, WORKING FORESTS, DEVELOP OPPORTUNITIES FOR LONGER-TERM MONITORING OF INDIVIDUAL AND COMMUNITIES OF AT-RISK SPECIES IN WORKING FOREST LANDSCAPES, AND RELATE THOSE SPECIES AND COMMUNITIES TO STAND AND LANDSCAPE-LEVEL FOREST CHARACTERISTICS. PROJECTS TO BE SUPPORTED MAY INCLUDE: SURVEYS OF THE AT-RISK DIANA FRITILLARY BUTTERFLY ON PRIVATE WORKING FOREST LAND. SURVEYS OF INSECT POLLINATOR COMMUNITIES IN WORKING FOREST STANDS OF VARYING AGES. EXAMINING THE ROLE OF PRIVATE WORKING FORESTS PLAY IN PROVIDING HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS ACROSS THEIR FULL LIFE CYCLE IN THE EASTERN U.S. CONDUCT SURVEYS AND HABITAT WORK ON IMPORTANT BAT SPECIES, INCLUDING THE LONG-EARED BAT, LITTLE BROWN BAT, AND TRICOLORED BAT. SURVEY TURTLES AND OTHER AQUATIC SPECIES, INCLUDING WOOD TURTLE, WESTERN POND TURTLE, AND ALLIGATOR SNAPPING TURTLE.THE WCI PROVIDES IMPORTANT DATA ON THE DISTRIBUTION AND ECOLOGY OF AT-RISK SPECIES. THIS COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION MODEL HAS GREATLY ENHANCED INFORMATION GATHERING AND SHARING WITH NATIONAL ALLIANCE OF FORESTRY OWNERS (NAFO), NATIONAL COUNCIL FOR AIR AND STREAM IMPROVEMENT (NCASI), US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, OTHER PARTNERS, AND OWNERS AND MANAGERS OF PRIVATE WORKING FORESTS.

THE EASTERN BEARD GRASS SKIPPER OR AROGOS SKIPPER (ATRYTONE AROGOS AROGOS) IS A CRITICALLY IMPERILED BUTTERFLY (G2G3T1T2 S1, NATURESERVE) FOUND IN DRY PRAIRIE, PINELAND, AND SANDHILL HABITATS IN THE EASTERN U.S. A SEPARATE IMPERILED SUBSPECIES, THE IOWA SKIPPER (ATRYTONE AROGOS IOWA), OCCURS IN THE MIDCONTINENT PRAIRIE GRASSLAND HABITATS AND HAS BEEN IN DECLINE SINCE AT LEAST THE 80 S. ALTHOUGH THE RANGE OF THE IOWA SKIPPER IS WIDESPREAD, IT IS PATCHILY DISTRIBUTED AND GENERALLY CONSIDERED RARE WITH NO POPULATIONS CONSIDERED SECURE. IT REMAINS UNKNOWN HOW THESE TWO GEOGRAPHICALLY SEPARATED SUBSPECIES DIFFER GENETICALLY AND WHETHER VARIOUS ECOTYPES WARRANT SUBSPECIES STATUS. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO HELP INFORM AN UPCOMING USFWS SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT. SPECIFICALLY, THE THREE PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) EXAMINE THE GENETIC CONNECTIVITY AND STRUCTURE OF THE EXTANT DISJOINTED POPULATIONS ACROSS FLORIDA, 2) ASSESS THE EVOLUTIONARY RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE DESCRIBED SUBSPECIES ATRYTONE AROGOS IOWA AND ATRYTONE AROGOS AROGOS  AND 3) SCREEN DNA BARCODE EXISTING SAMPLES USING COI TO DETERMINE SPECIES-LEVEL IDENTIFICATIONS ON MATERIAL COLLECTED BY THE RAPID RESPONSE TEAM.

THE ARIZONA MONARCH COLLABORATIVE (AMC) WAS FORMED IN 2019 TO BRING TOGETHER PEOPLE WORKING ON MONARCH AND POLLINATOR CONSERVATION IN THE STATE OF ARIZONA. CONTRIBUTORS TO THE AMC INCLUDE LOCAL PERSONNEL FROM FEDERAL AGENCIES, STATE AGENCIES, NON-PROFITS, UNIVERSITIES, AND TRIBES. AMC HAS ACCOMPLISHED A FEW KEY CONSERVATION ACTIONS SINCE ITS FOUNDING, BUT IT HAS THE POTENTIAL TO BE MUCH MORE IMPACTFUL WITH A DEDICATED STATE COORDINATOR. BASED ON SUCCESSFUL STATE COORDINATORS IN EASTERN STATES, WE PROPOSED TO HIRE AN ARIZONA STATE COORDINATOR THAT WILL FURTHER ORGANIZE THE EFFORTS OF THE AMC, CREATE A VOLUNTARY STATE ACTION PLAN, CONTRIBUTE TO WESTERN ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES MONARCH AND POLLINATOR GROUP, STRENGTHEN PARTNERSHIPS, AND IMPROVE COMMUNICATIONS. AS THE FIRST STATE IN THE WESTERN FLYWAY TO HAVE A STATE MONARCH COLLABORATIVE, WE ALSO PLAN TO CREATE A RESOURCE GUIDE ON THE ROLES, RESPONSIBILITIES AND LESSONS LEARNED FROM ADDING A STATE COORDINATOR.

THE GULF OF MEXICO ALLIANCE (GOMA) IS IN A UNIQUE POSITION TO REDUCE BARRIERS AND CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR CAREER GROWTH THROUGH NETWORKING, MENTORING, PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING, AND HANDS ON EXPERIENCE. TO SUPPORT UNDERREPRESENTED AND UNDERSERVED GROUPS, GOMA HAS IDENTIFIED INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITIES AS A WAY TO ENGAGE EARLY CAREER SCIENTISTS AND STUDENTS.THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT GOMA S UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS IN PAID INTERNSHIPS AT GOMA S PARTNER STATE AGENCIES. PARTICIPANTS FROM DIVERSE BACKGROUNDS ACROSS THE FIVE GULF STATES (ALABAMA, FLORIDA, LOUISIANA, MISSISSIPPI, AND TEXAS) WILL GAIN MENTORING AND HANDS ON EXPERIENCE IN COASTAL MANAGEMENT CAREERS. INTERNSHIP TOPICS MAY INCLUDE  COASTAL COMMUNITY RESILIENCE, DATA SHARING, HABITAT RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT, WATER RESOURCES, AND WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES.

TO CONTINUE TO ADVANCE THE CENTRAL GRASSLAND ROADMAP INITIATIVE, WHICH CURRENTLY HAS INPUT AND SUPPORT FROM MORE THAN 600 PEOPLE REPRESENTING 200  ORGANIZATIONS, WE NEED A DEDICATED GRASSLAND DIRECTOR. THE DIRECTOR WILL ENSURE COORDINATION AND COMMUNICATION OF PARTNERS AND EFFORTS GOING FORWARD. BIRD CONSERVANCY OF THE ROCKIES WAS THE CATALYZING ORGANIZATION, AND THE PLANNING TEAM RECOMMENDS THE POSITION BE HOSTED BY BIRD CONSERVANCY TO HELP WITH CONTINUITY AND MOMENTUM. THE POSITION WILL BE CO- SUPERVISED BY A SMALL SUBSET OF 2-3 FUNDING PARTNERS. THEY WILL ALSO HAVE AN ADVISORY TEAM REPRESENTING THE BROADER PARTNERSHIP OF 5-7 WHO WILL HELP WITH STRATEGIC OVERSIGHT.

THE NORTHEAST ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES (NEAFWA) IS PARTNERING WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS) AND THE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT INSTITUTE (WMI) TO HIRE A NORTHEAST REGIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE HEALTH COORDINATOR. THE COORDINATOR WILL ENCOURAGE AND SUPPORT THE NETWORK OF FISH AND WILDLIFE HEALTH PRACTITIONERS IN THEIR WORK TO ADDRESS ZOONOTIC DISEASES AND OTHER FISH AND WILDLIFE HEALTH ISSUES ACROSS THE NORTHEAST REGION. THE ABILITY TO COLLABORATE WILL BE CRITICAL, AND THE COORDINATOR WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE NEAFWA MEMBER STATES, THE FWS, OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES, ACADEMIA AND OTHER INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS TO DEVELOP REGIONAL STRATEGIES FOR PREVENTING, DETECTING, CONTROLLING AND POTENTIALLY ERADICATING IMPORTANT WILDLIFE DISEASES IN AN EFFORT TO MINIMIZE IMPACTS TO WILDLIFE, LIVESTOCK AND PEOPLE.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSED WORK IS TO BETTER CHARACTERIZE THE NATAL ORIGINS OF WESTERN MONARCH  DANAUS PLEXIPPUS  BUTTERFLIES USING STABLE ISOTOPES AND CARDENOLIDES. THIS WORK WILL BUILD ON PREVIOUS STUDIES AND MAY HELP TO EXPLAIN HOW THE POPULATION INCREASED FROM LESS THAN 2000 INDIVIDUALS IN 2020 TO NEARLY 250,000 INDIVIDUALS IN 2021. DESPITE THEIR CONSERVATION IMPORTANCE AND RECENT POPULATION DECLINES, THE NATAL ORIGINS OF WESTERN MONARCHS REMAIN POORLY KNOWN. IMPROVING KNOWLEDGE OF THESE NATAL ORIGINS WOULD INFORM SPECIES PROTECTION AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT.

TOGETHER IN PARTNERSHIP WITH MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY  MSU  AND LOCALLY BASED SOCIAL SCIENTISTS, U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  FWS  SOUTHEAST REGION SOCIAL SCIENTISTS WILL IDENTIFY AND IMPLEMENT METHODS AND TOOLS WITHIN THE SOCIAL SCIENCES TO ADDRESS THE MOST PRESSING PRIORITIES OF THE REGION, INCLUDING ENHANCING PUBLIC PERCEPTION OF DECISIONS RELATED TO HABITAT CONSERVATION AND THREATENED, ENDANGERED, AND AT RISK SPECIES, EFFECTIVELY ENGAGING HISTORICALLY UNDERSERVED PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, AND ADDRESSING CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION ACROSS THE REGION, PARTICULARLY IN UNDERSERVED URBAN COMMUNITIES  SOCIAL SCIENTISTS WITHIN RELEVANT ORGANIZATIONS, INSTITUTIONS, AND COMMUNITIES WILL BE ENGAGED AS NEEDED TO DEVELOP SPECIFIC SCOPES OF WORK TO IMPLEMENT AGREED UPON STRATEGIES

THIS PROJECT EXTENDS THE SCENARIO PLANNING CAPABILITIES OF THE WEB BASED SOUTHEAST BLUEPRINT ACTION IMPACT TOOL  AIT   THE AIT IS A SPATIALLY EXPLICIT, WEB BASED SCENARIO PLANNING AND DECISION SUPPORT TOOL THAT ALLOWS USERS TO ASSESS CURRENT AND FUTURE HEALTH, FUNCTION, AND CONNECTIVITY OF PRIORITY ECOSYSTEMS IN PROJECT AREAS OF INTEREST, WITH PARTICULAR INTEREST IN AREAS PRIORITIZED UNDER THE SOUTHEAST BLUEPRINT  THE AIT ALLOWS FOR PLANNERS TO PREDICT OUTCOMES OF CONSERVATION ACTION IN POTENTIAL PROJECT AREAS TO INFORM AND IMPROVE RETURN ON INVESTMENT IN CONSERVATION DECISION MAKING AND ULTIMATELY TO HELP MEET ECOSYSTEM TARGETS OF THE SOUTHEAST CONSERVATION ADAPTATION STRATEGY  IN THE SECOND PHASE OF THE AIT PROJECT WE WILL INCORPORATE COMPLEX STOCHASTIC MODELS THAT ALLOW FOR UNCERTAINTY IN MANAGEMENT OUTCOMES TO HELP OPTIMIZE AND TARGET DELIVERY OF CONSERVATION ACTIONS WITHIN AREAS OF INTEREST FROM LANDSCAPE TO ECOREGIONAL SCALES  MANAGEMENT IMPLICATION  THIS PROJECT HAS DIRECT APPLICATION TO MANAGEMENT ACTIONS GUIDED BY THE SOUTHEAST CONSERVATION BLUEPRINT  OUR WORK WILL DIRECTLY INFORM DECISIONS REGARDING OPTIMUM CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO TAKE IN A PROJECT AREA OF INTEREST THAT WILL IMPROVE MAINTAIN THE HEALTH, FUNCTION, AND CONNECTIVITY OF THE LANDSCAPE OF INTEREST, PARTICULARLY IN THE FACE OF LANDSCAPE CHANGE  THE STOCHASTIC MODELS WILL HELP MANAGERS BETTER UNDERSTAND THE BREADTH OF UNCERTAINTY IN OUTCOMES RELATED TO THEIR ON THE GROUND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS  MOREOVER, ACTIONS WILL BE DIRECTLY LINKED TO THE BLUEPRINT VIA THE INCLUSION OF BLUEPRINT INDICATORS TO INFORM MANAGEMENT WITHIN BLUEPRINT PRIORITY AREAS AND ESTIMATE PROGRESS TOWARDS THE SECAS GOAL

ENSURING THE FUTURE OF AT-RISK SPECIES, MIGRATORY BIRDS, AND THEIR HABITATS REQUIRES THE EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION OF PROPER QUANTITY, QUALITY, AVAILABILITY, AND DISTRIBUTION OF HABITATS TO MEET THE SERVICES CORE RESPONSIBILITY OF MANAGING THESE SPECIES. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO ADDRESS THE NEED FOR HIGH QUALITY SCIENCE AND DECISION SUPPORT THROUGH SUPPORTING UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AND FACULTY MENTORS FROM BETHUNE-COOKMAN UNIVERSITY TO COLLECT AND ANALYZE DATA AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS RELATED TO AT-RISK SPECIES IN THE SOUTHEASTERN US WHILE EXPOSING UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS TO USFWS RELATED CAREERS. THIS PROPOSAL LEVERAGES AND SEEKS TO EXPAND UPON THE SPRING 2022 COLLABORATION BETWEEN USFWS AND B-CUS RISE SCHOLARS PROGRAM IN WHICH SIX UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AND FACULTY MENTORS PARTICIPATED IN 8-WEEK INTERNSHIPS CREATING USFWS OUTREACH MATERIALS, ANALYZING USFWS DATA, CONTRIBUTING TO THE ANALYSIS OF BIOLOGICAL OPINIONS, AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE LANDSCAPE RECOVERY TOOL AND EFFECTS PATHWAYS DESCRIPTIONS. THE EXPANSION OF THIS PROGRAM WILL SUPPORT INCREASED INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITIES FOR 1-3 STUDENTS PER YEAR FOR THE NEXT 5 YEARS ALONG WITH TRAVEL FOR STUDENTS TO PRIORITY HABITATS AND USFWS FACILITIES. A MINIMUM OF SIX, 8- TO 16-WEEK LONG INTERNSHIPS, DEPENDING ON THE PROJECT, EACH ACADEMIC SEMESTER WOULD ASSIGN STUDENTS TO WORK ON GENERATING OUTREACH MATERIALS, DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS, AND OR TOOL DEVELOPMENT TO ASSIST IN AT-RISK AND MIGRATORY BIRD SPECIES MANAGEMENT. DURING THE INTERNSHIP STUDENTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN WEEKLY MEETINGS, CAREER SERVICES TRAININGS, FIELD TRIPS, AND INTERNSHIP OR RESEARCH ACTIVITIES WHICH WILL CULMINATE IN PRESENTATIONS AT A CONFERENCE OR SYMPOSIUM. STUDENT ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, STUDENT SATISFACTION, ACQUISITION OF SKILLS AND COMPETENCIES, AND WORKFORCE PREPARATION WILL BE ASSESSED IN EACH CYCLE WITH STUDENTS PARTICIPATING IN PRE POSTTEST EVALUATIONS AND MENTORS COMPLETING DIRECT ASSESSMENTS OF STUDENT COMPETENCIES AND SKILLS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPLY DATA TO SUPPORT VARIOUS COMPONENTS OF THE SOUTHEAST CONSERVATIONADAPTATION STRATEGY S  SECAS  SOUTHEAST CONSERVATION BLUEPRINT  BLUEPRINT   SARP ROUTINELY COMPILES DATA,ANALYZES, AND PRIORITIES AQUATIC BARRIERS AND ALL AREAS COVERED BY THE BLUEPRINT EXCEPT FOR WEST VIRGINIA AND THE US VIRGIN ISLANDS  THESE DATA AND SUBSEQUENT ANALYSES ARE UTILIZED BY SECAS TO DERIVE A NETWORK COMPLEXITYINDICATOR  THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE SARP TO PROVIDE A MORE COMPLETE ASSESSMENT FOR WEST VIRGINIA TO MAKE IT MORECOMPARABLE TO THE REST OF THE SOUTHEAST  ADDITIONALLY, SARP WILL PROVIDE BARRIER INFORMATION FOR THE US VIRGINISLANDS SO THAT SECAS CAN EXPAND THE NETWORK COMPLEXITY ANALYSIS TO THE CARIBBEAN REGION  IN ADDITION, SARP WILL ALSO PROVIDE DISTRIBUTION DATA FOR AQUATIC IMPERILED SPECIES FOR WEST VIRGINIA, US VIRGIN ISLANDS, AND PUERTO RICO SO THAT SECAS CAN EXPAND THE IMPERILED AQUATIC SPECIES INDICATOR IN THESE THREE REGIONS

THIS EXPERIENTIAL PROJECT PROGRAM WILL ENHANCE SCIENCE BASED RESEARCH AND OTHER COLLABORATIONS BETWEEN MINORITY SERVING INSTITUTIONS  MSI  AND USFWS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE ONGOING SCIENCE NEEDS OF THE SOUTHEAST REGION AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF TOOLS THAT INFORM DECISION MAKING FOR REGIONAL AND NATIONAL CONSERVATION PRIORITIES  THIS PROJECT WILL BE AN IMPORTANT OPPORTUNITY FOR STUDENT ENGAGEMENT AND A POTENTIAL RECRUITMENT TOOL TO ATTRACT AND RETAIN HISTORICALLY MARGINALIZED STUDENTS INTO USFWS RELATED CAREERS

THE FOOTHILL YELLOW LEGGED FROG HAS DECLINED FROM OVER HALF OF ITS HISTORICAL RANGE, PROMPTING ITS LISTING UNDER THE CALIFORNIA ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND ITS PROPOSED LISTING UNDER THE U S  ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  THE SOUTH COAST CLADE  SCC , A GENETICALLY DISTINCT PORTION OF THE FROGS RANGE, IS AT THE HIGHEST RISK OF EXTINCTION  AN ULTIMATE CONSERVATION GOAL FOR THIS SPECIES IS TO REINTRODUCE IT TO HISTORICALLY OCCUPIED PORTIONS OF THE RANGE  THE PURPOSE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE STATUS OF THE SMALL REMAINING POPULATIONS, THE SUITABILITY OF POTENTIAL REINTRODUCTION SITES, AND THE SUITABILITY OF SOURCE POPULATIONS FOR REINTRODUCTIONS  TO DO THIS, THE PROJECT WILL  1  LEVERAGE EXISTING RESEARCH TO BOLSTER REPRODUCTION IN SMALL, ISOLATED POPULATIONS THAT MAY SERVE AS SOURCE SITES FOR REINTRODUCTIONS  2  TRANSLOCATE EGG MASSES TO SUITABLE HABITATS IN ORDER TO A  BEGIN REESTABLISHING A POPULATION IN A STREAM WHERE THE SPECIES IS ABSENT  AND B  CONDUCT A PILOT TRANSLOCATION TO A NEW CREEK TO DETERMINE THE BEST METHODS FOR INCREASING THE SCALE OF EGG REARING THERE  DELIVERABLES INCLUDE AN ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORT DETAILING PRELIMINARY FINDINGS AND PROJECT PROGRESS  A FINAL REPORT DETAILING RESULTS FROM ADDRESSING PROJECT OBJECTIVES, WITH RECOMMENDATIONS FOR RECOVERY ACTIONS BASED ON RESULTS  AND A DRAFT MANUSCRIPT DETAILING FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS, SUITABLE FOR PUBLICATION IN A PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL

THE CROWN LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION DESIGN IS BRINGING TOGETHER THE GREAT PEOPLE, SCIENCE AND PLANNING ACROSS THE CROWN OF THE CONTINENT ECOSYSTEM  CCE  INTO A UNIFIED LANDSCAPE SCALE CONSERVATION  DESIGN   LCD  THAT CONSIDERS NOT ONLY WILDLIFE AND ECOSYSTEMS, BUT CULTURAL, SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC PRIORITIES AS WELL  TOGETHER, PARTNERS ACROSS THE CCE WILL ENVISION WHAT CONDITIONS ARE ESSENTIAL FOR A HEALTHY FUTURE LANDSCAPE, AND WHAT STRESSORS OR CHANGES MAY LIMIT THEIR CONSERVATION  BY FEEDING HIGH QUALITY, CCE WIDE DATA INTO AN OPTIMIZATION MODEL, WE CAN DETERMINE WHERE ON THE LANDSCAPE IT IS MOST EFFECTIVE TO CONCENTRATE EFFORT AND RESOURCES  THE RESULTANT  ROADMAP , WHICH CONSIDERS MULTIPLE CONSERVATION PRIORITIES ON THE LANDSCAPE SIMULTANEOUSLY, CAN BE USED BY AGENCY MANAGERS TO GUIDE LANDSCAPE LEVEL CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION EFFORTS THROUGHOUT THE CCE

GRANITE OUTCROPS ARE HOME TO NUMEROUS RARE AND THREATENED PLANT SPECIES, INCLUDING SEVERAL LISTED UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE STATUS AND SUCCESS OF SEVERAL HABITAT ENHANCEMENT AND CREATION EFFORTS THAT WERE COMPLETED IN GRANITE OUTCROPS BY VARIOUSSTAKEHOLDERS BETWEEN 2000?2005, INCLUDING POOL DEEPENING, LIP REPAIR, SOIL EXCAVATION/ADDITION, VEGETATION REMOVAL, AND TARGET SPECIES INTRODUCTIONS. THIS PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ANALYZE AND EVALUATE HOW POOL ARCHITECTURE AND TARGET SPECIES ABUNDANCE HAVE FARED SINCE HABITAT ALTERATION AND PREPARE A FINAL REPORT FOR USFWS. SPECIFICALLY, HISTORICAL DATA WILL BE COMPARED TO RECENT SURVEY DATA AND THE VARIOUS STAKEHOLDERS MOST INVOLVED IN EACH PROJECT WILL BE INTERVIEWED. THIS WILL HELP MEDIATE THE LIMITED DOCUMENTATION THAT EXISTS OF EACH PROJECT'S PROCESS AND WILL HIGHLIGHT A SUCCESSFUL CONSERVATION STORY IN GEORGIA.

THIS PROJECT RESPONDS TO AN IDENTIFIED NEED TO HARNESS PRACTITIONERS  EXPERIENCE AND OUTCOMES OF LARGESCALE HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS IN THE SAGEBRUSH BIOME TO INFORM FUTURE RESTORATION TREATMENTS AND  ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF ONGOING PROJECTS  THE PROJECT WILL CAPITALIZE ON EXISTING RANGELAND RESTORATION  PROJECT DATABASES  E G  THE LAND TREATMENT DIGITAL LIBRARY  LTDL , LAND TREATMENT EXPLORATION TOOL  LTET , AND OTHERS CURRENTLY BEING MANAGED AT LOCAL AND STATE LEVELS  AT A TIME WHEN BOTH STATE AND  FEDERAL FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES ARE ENABLING LAND MANAGERS TO TREAT SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM THREATS,  PARTICULARLY INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES, AT LARGE LANDSCAPE SCALES  WE WILL IMPLEMENT A ROBUST, YET PRACTICAL  MONITORING PLAN FOR LANDSCAPE SCALE TREATMENTS SPANNING ADMINISTRATIVE BOUNDARIES AND WORK WITH U S   FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, U S  GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, AND END USERS TO COLLECT  PRE AND POST TREATMENT DATA AND CUSTOMIZE THE EXISTING LTET PLATFORM TO BETTER INTEGRATE MONITORING  DATA FOR DECISION MAKING  THE INSTITUTE FOR NATURAL RESOURCES  INR  AT OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY WILL WORK  CLOSELY WITH THESE PARTNERS TO CONDUCT FIELD SAMPLING OF MULTIPLE TREATMENTS EACH YEAR, AS WELL AS SERVING  ON THE ADVISORY TEAM FOR THE PROJECT  THE ENHANCED TOOL WILL ALLOW RESOURCE MANAGERS TO  1  ACCESS  CUSTOMIZABLE AND MEANINGFUL CASE STUDIES OF RESTORATION EFFORTS IMPLEMENTED ACROSS THE SAGEBRUSH  BIOME USING THE FIRST LANDSCAPE SCALE DYNAMIC TREATMENT DATABASE THAT RELATES TREATMENT OUTCOMES TO LANDSCAPE, VEGETATION, CLIMATE, AND TREATMENT VARIABLES  AND THEREBY 2  BETTER UNDERSTAND WHY  RESTORATION SUCCEEDS OR FAILS, HOW TO ADAPTIVELY MANAGE AND PLAN FOR FUTURE PROJECTS, AND IF RESTORATION  INVESTMENTS ARE GROWING OR PROTECTING VITAL HABITAT

THE HIGH DIVIDE REGION, SPANNING EASTERN IDAHO AND WESTERN MONTANA, COVERS APPROXIMATELY 138,000 SQUARE KILOMETERS  THE AREA CONTAINS THE HEADWATERS OF THE MISSOURI AND COLUMBIA WATERSHEDS AND IS VITAL FOR MAINTAINING CURRENT AND POTENTIAL CONNECTIVITY ACROSS PRIVATELY OWNED LANDS BETWEEN THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE ECOSYSTEM, THE CENTRAL IDAHO WILDERNESS, AND THE CROWN OF THE CONTINENT ECOSYSTEM  THE HIGH DIVIDE IS HOME TO OUTSTANDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION, IMPORTANT SAGEBRUSH STEPPE AND FORESTED HABITAT, AND ESSENTIAL WORKING RANCHLANDS, ALL WITHIN A REGION SUSCEPTIBLE TO ENTRENCHED, POLARIZED VIEWS ON CONSERVATION  THE LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION DESIGN PROCESS PROVIDES A FRAMEWORK TO CONTINUE TO BRING MANY OF THESE DIVERSE INTERESTS TOGETHER OVER A COMMON CONCERN FOR THE HIGH DIVIDE TO PRODUCE A SHARED, LONG TERM, STRATEGIC LANDSCAPE VISION THAT ENSURES PEOPLE LIVING AND WORKING IN THE REGION CAN TAKE ACTION THAT WILL BE SUSTAINED BY THE WHOLE COMMUNITY  WITHOUT IT, CONSERVATION ENDEAVORS WOULD BE DISJOINTED BETWEEN INTEREST GROUPS, AND WOULD MOST LIKELY NOT HAVE THE INPUT OF THE LOCAL COMMUNITIES, ULTIMATELY LEADING TO PATCHWORK AND THUS INEFFECTIVE CONSERVATION EFFORTS

THE RIVER CONDITIONS TOOL  RCT , CREATED BY U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  REGION 6 SCIENCE APPLICATIONS  R6 SA , IS A PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE WEB TOOL WHERE PLANNED DATA MANAGEMENT AND THE INTEGRATION OF SCATTERED INFORMATION HAS BEEN ACCOMPLISHED IN THE GEOGRAPHY OF 31 WATERSHEDS IN MONTANA AND WYOMING  FOR THE CURRENT RCT GEOGRAPHY COVERAGE, THIS TOOL HAS HELPED SOLVE ISSUES REGARDING THE LACK OF REAL TIME SITUATIONAL AWARENESS AND COMMUNICATION TO ALL RIVERINE STAKEHOLDERS AND STREAM USERS FOR CONSERVATION PURPOSES  THIS WEB BASED TOOL IS A ONE STOP SHOP FOR STREAM USERS  LAND OWNERS, LAND WATERSHED MANAGERS, SCIENTISTS, AGRICULTURE COMMUNITY, RECREATIONALISTS, ETC  AND HAS BEEN EMBEDDED INTO STAKEHOLDER WEBSITES FOR PUBLIC USE  THIS TOOL S FOCUS ON DROUGHT MANAGEMENT PLANNING, ALIGNS WITH DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR, USFWS, SA, STATE, AND WATERSHED PRIORITIES, AND INCLUDES OTHER ANCILLARY BENEFITS  FLOODING, OUTREACH, MONITORING, AGRICULTURE, SPORT FISHING, CONSERVATION ACTIONS, ETC    R6 SA HAS DEVELOPED THIS TOOL IN HOUSE AS A CUSTOM AND SCALABLE TOOL TO EXPAND TO OTHER GEOGRAPHIES THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EXPAND THE CURRENT WEB TOOL COVERAGE AREA GEOGRAPHY TO 8 10WATERSHEDS PER YEAR ON A THREE YEAR CYCLE  FY22, FY23, FY24 FUNDING NEEDED FOR THE 3 YEARCYCLE   ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DIGITALLY LINKING FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL REAL TIME HYDROLOGICALCONDITION TRACKING  E G , STREAM GAGES  AND WARNING SYSTEMS TO INSTANTANEOUSLY ALERT STREAM USERS TO WATER AND FISHERIES USE AND RESTRICTIONS  THE TOOL DYNAMICALLY DISPLAYS RECENT AND CURRENT CONDITION ALLOWING USERS TO UNDERSTAND AND PLAN AROUND EXPECTED CHANGES IN RIVER CONDITIONFACILITATING EFFICIENT DECISION MAKING  BY LEVERAGING THIS TOOL S PREVIOUS PROGRESS, SCALABILITY ANDPOTENTIAL WIDESPREAD USE AND WORKING IN SYNC WITH THE R6 SA SCIENCE COORDINATOR ON USFWSPRIORITY AREAS  IE  HIGH DIVIDE LCD, FWS REFUGES , THIS COVERAGE EXPANSION WORK HAS A HIGHLIKELIHOOD OF SUCCESS

UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION (NFWF) AND U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE (FWS) WILL MANAGE THE DELAWARE WATERSHED CONSERVATION FUND. AUTHORIZED BY THE NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION ESTABLISHMENT ACT, 16 U.S.C. 3701 OF 1984, NFWF WILL ASSIST FWS BY DEVELOPING A COMPETITIVE GRANT PROGRAM WITH THE GOAL OF IMPROVING RESTORATION AND PROTECTION OF THE RESOURCES IN THE DELAWARE RIVER WATERSHED BY ENHANCING EFFORTS TO COORDINATE THE MANY, ALREADY COMMITTED, PARTNERS. NFWF HAS A LONGSTANDING COMMITMENT TO WATERSHED RESTORATION AND STEWARDSHIP, FOCUSED ON DEMONSTRABLE IMPROVEMENTS FOR NATURAL RESOURCES AND SOCIAL VALUES, INCLUDING NATIVE BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF KEY INDICATOR SPECIES. NFWF HAS A TRACK RECORD OF ENGAGEMENT WITH COMMUNITY LEADERS AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND HAS PREVIOUSLY ASSISTED FWS USING THIS PROVEN GRANT PROGRAM MODEL. THE DELAWARE WATERSHED CONSERVATION FUND (DWCF) WILL MAXIMIZE CONSERVATION, BOLSTER THE ECONOMY, FURTHER PROTECT COMMUNITIES, IMPROVE HUMAN HEALTH, PROVIDE GREATER OUTDOOR RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES, AND HELP BUILD A MORE ADAPTABLE WATERSHED FOR ALL CITIZENS TO ENJOY TODAY AND INTO THE FUTURE.

THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A FOUNDATION SEED PROGRAM IN NEVADA WILL PROVIDE A RELIABLE SOURCE OF GENETICALLY APPROPRIATE FOUNDATION SEED TO BE USED FOR PROPAGATION PURPOSES BY PRODUCERS HERE AND IN SURROUNDING STATES  THIS WILL MINIMIZE TRANSACTION COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH PRODUCERS PROCURING FOUNDATION SEED AND SUPPORT THE SUPPLY OF CERTIFIED SEED PRODUCED VIA SEED INCREASE FOR RESTORATION PROJECTS IN NEVADA, STABILIZING THE MARKET FOR NEVADA SEED PRODUCERS AND END USERS  IN ADDITION TO ENHANCING ACCESS TO GENETICALLY APPROPRIATE SEED, WE INTEND TO TRACK SPECIFIC METRICS THROUGH AN INVENTORY DATABASE DURING THE GROWING SEASON TO ENSURE THAT PRODUCERS ARE MEETING CERTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS  THE DATABASE WILL INCLUDE SPECIES NAME AND COLLECTION INFORMATION AS WELL AS SEED ANALYSIS REPORTS, STORAGE INFORMATION, AND GROWER INFORMATION  QUANTIFIABLE METRICS WILL BE MONITORED DURING THE GROWING SEASON TO ENSURE THAT PRODUCERS ARE MAINTAINING CERTIFICATION STANDARDS AS PRESCRIBED BY THE ASSOCIATION OF OFFICIAL SEED CERTIFYING AGENCIES  AOSCA   THESE MONITORING METHODS WILL ASSIST TO SATISFY OUR GOAL OF INCREASING TOTAL AVAILABILITY OF LOCALLY ADAPTED SEED AND WILL INCLUDE  A  FIELD ACREAGE, B  NOXIOUS WEED PRESENCE, C  SEED ZONE, D  ECOREGION, E  TOTAL AMOUNT OF SEED AWARDED, F  TOTAL YIELDS, AND G  VARIOUS PRODUCTION METHOD ELEMENTS

THIS RESEARCH WILL SERVE AS A TEST OF CURRENT SEED TRANSFER GUIDANCE USED IN RESTORATION  THE RESULTS WILL EITHER SUPPORT THE UTILITY OF CURRENT SEED TRANSFER GUIDANCE, OR IT WILL DEMONSTRATE THAT FURTHER KNOWLEDGE IS NEEDED TO IMPROVE SEED TRANSFER GUIDANCE FOR RESTORATION OF DIVERSE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM PLANT COMMUNITIES  IN COMBINATION WITH SUPPORT FROM USFS, THIS WILL FULLY FUND A UNIQUE 5 YEAR PHD PROJECT THAT WILL NOT ONLY PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION ABOUT THE PERFORMANCE OF SEED ZONES IN SOME OF THE MOST HIGHLY IMPACTED AREAS OF SAGEBRUSH STEPPE HABITAT, IT WILL ALSO TRAIN ANOTHER PHD STUDENT AND MULTIPLE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IN PLANT ECOLOGY AND RESTORATION OF THE GREAT BASIN  STUDENTS WORKING IN THE LEGER LAB FREQUENTLY SECURE EMPLOYMENT IN STATE, FEDERAL, AND NON PROFIT ENTITIES WORKING TO IMPROVE GREAT BASIN PLANT COMMUNITIES, SO THIS PROJECT HAS THE POTENTIAL TO INCREASE WORKFORCE CAPACITY AS WELL AS SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE

THIS WORK WILL PROVIDE ASSISTANCE AS IDENTIFIED IN THE PHASE I STRATEGY DOCUMENT TO INFORM NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT OF THE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM IN WESTERN US. THE WORK TASKS AND ASSISTANCE BUILD ON RECENT SPATIAL MODELING WORK CONDUCTED WITH THE SAGEBRUSH LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION DESIGN TEAM TO IDENTIFY AND MODEL THE DISTRIBUTION AND PATTERN OF SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM INTEGRITY, INCLUDING ASSISTANCE IN GUIDING THE INTER-AGENCY WORK GROUP/TEAM, COORDINATED BY THE WESTERN ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES. THESE INCLUDE DEVELOPING SPATIAL MODELS TO IDENTIFY CORE, GROW, AND OTHER AREAS IMPORTANT FOR SAGEBRUSH CONSERVATION, APPLYING THIS MODEL TO YEARS 2001-2020, ESTIMATING UNCERTAINTY OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON THE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM INTEGRITY, AND GENERATING A ECOSYSTEM CONNECTIVITY MODEL.

THE GRASSLAND AND SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS TEAMS REPORT (FWS 2021) MENTIONS CLIMATE CHANGE AS A KEY THREAT TO SUSTAINED CONSERVATION OF GRASSLAND BIRD POPULATIONS AND GRASSLAND ASSOCIATED AQUATIC SPECIES (E.G., APPENDIX A,B, PAGES 8-9) YET CONSERVATION DESIGN AND DELIVERY ELEMENTS OF THE GRASSLAND ECOSYSTEM TEAM (GET) HAS YET TO EXPLICITLY ADDRESS POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF AND RESPONSE TO CHANGING CLIMATE CONDITIONS AS THEY IMPLEMENT STRATEGIC HABITAT CONSERVATION ACROSS USFWS TRUST RESOURCES ACROSS THE GRASSLAND BIOME. FURTHERMORE, CONVERSATIONS WITH GET COORDINATOR JOHN CARLSON AND THE GET TEAM INDICATE THE GET TEAM WILL GREATLY BENEFIT FROM TRAINING AS THE SHC PROCESS ITERATES THROUGH ADDITIONAL THREATS TO ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION AND MANAGEMENT.USFWS PARTNERS AT THREE US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTERS (CASC) HAVE BEEN FUNDING CLIMATE AND CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE FOCUSED ON GRASSLAND ECOSYSTEMS FOR THE PAST 15 YEARS.THE CASCS HAVE ACCESS TO VOLUMES OF CLIMATE SCIENCE AND CLIMATE ADAPTATION EXPERTS AND ARE DEVELOPING CONCEPTS AND TECHNIQUES TO CREATE A WESTERN CLIMATE TRAINING CENTER. THE CASC AND GET TEAMS HAVE A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO BOTH DEVELOP AND DELIVER HIGHLY TARGETED CLIMATE ADAPTATION TRAINING AND BUILD OUT RELATIONSHIPS AND PROCESSES FOR ENHANCING USFWS STAFF'S CAPACITY TO IMPLEMENT CLIMATE-SMART CONSERVATION TO THE SERVICE'S TRUST RESOURCES.WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A SERIES OF CLIMATE SCIENCE WEBINARS LEADING UP TO A ONE-DAY CLIMATE ADAPTATION FOR GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT WORKSHOP IN CALENDAR YEAR 2022. AGENDA AND TOPICS, CURRENTLY UNDER DEVELOPMENT, WILL BE BASED ON PRE-SURVEYS WHERE GET MEMBERS IDENTIFIED GAPS IN THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITY TO MANAGE GRASSLANDS UNDER CHANGING CLIMATES AND WILL INCLUDE INVITED RESEARCHERS WHO HAVE BEEN WORKING UNDER CASC GUIDANCE AS PRESENTERS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS THREE-YEAR COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO SUPPORT, COORDINATE AND STRENGTHEN LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION IN THE UNITED STATES AND TRANSBOUNDARY REGIONS THROUGH COLLABORATION AND LEVERAGING OF RESOURCES AMONG THE SERVICE AND ITS MANY PARTNERS TO ENHANCE SPECIES AND HABITAT CONSERVATION AND PROMOTE RELATED BENEFITS INCLUDING PUBLIC ACCESS FOR RECREATION, MITIGATING AND ADAPTING TO CLIMATE-CHANGE THREATS, PROTECTION OF WATER QUALITY, AND SUPPORTING THE WORKING LANDS ECONOMY. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES:1.ASSISTING THE SERVICE WITH IDENTIFICATION OF LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION ISSUES, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY NEEDS, AND CONSERVATION SOLUTIONS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH OTHER GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, INDIGENOUS ORGANIZATIONS, PHILANTHROPIES, NONPROFIT GROUPS, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND BUSINESS INTERESTS.2.ASSISTING THE SERVICE WITH IMPLEMENTATION OF SCIENCE AND MANAGEMENT PROJECTS TO ADDRESS SHARED PRIORITIES WITH OTHER GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, INDIGENOUS ORGANIZATIONS, PHILANTHROPIES, NONPROFIT GROUPS, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND BUSINESS INTERESTS.3.FACILITATING COLLABORATION AMONG THE SERVICE AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS FOCUSED ON SCIENCE NEEDS OF AT-RISK AND LISTED SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS.4.CONDUCTING RESEARCH AND SHARING DATA AND TOOLS RELATED TO LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION.5.PROMOTING ENGAGEMENT WITH NONTRADITIONAL PARTNERS TO BROADEN THE BENEFITS OF LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES.6.PROVIDING FUNDING AND TRAINING TO BUILD THE CAPACITY OF LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION PARTNERSHIPS.
